conclusion: The wire ab is suspended in a uniform magnetic field B perpendicular to the plane of the paper and into the paper. The wire has a length L. A current I flows from a to b.

premise: A current I flows through the wire in a magnetic field B.
conclusion: A magnetic force F_m acts on the wire.

premise: The magnitude of the magnetic force is given by F_m = I L B.
conclusion: The direction of the force is determined by the right-hand rule. Since the current flows from a to b and the magnetic field is into the paper, the force is directed upwards.

premise: When the current I flows from a to b, the magnetic force F_m = I L B acts upwards.
conclusion: The reading of one of the spring scales, F1, is the weight of the wire minus the magnetic force: F1 = W - I L B, where W is the weight of the wire.

premise: When the current is reversed and its magnitude becomes 2I, the current flows from b to a.
conclusion: The magnetic force now acts downwards: F_m = 2I L B.

premise: The magnetic force now acts downwards: F_m = 2I L B.
conclusion: The reading of one of the spring scales, F2, is the weight of the wire plus the magnetic force: F2 = W + 2I L B.

premise: From the first scenario: F1 = W - I L B. From the second scenario: F2 = W + 2I L B.
conclusion: Subtract the first equation from the second: F2 - F1 = (W + 2I L B) - (W - I L B)

premise: F2 - F1 = 2I L B + I L B

conclusion: Solve for B: B = (F2 - F1) / (3I L)

premise: Solve for B: B = (F2 - F1) / (3I L)
conclusion: The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity B is: B = (F2 - F1) / (3I L)
